avoid_unless_designer.description: Low-value materials unless from notable brand

acrylic.notes: Low value. Pills easily. Avoid unless vintage designer.

polyester.notes: Generally low value. Exception: 1970s designer polyester, Japanese designer poly.

spandex_elastane.notes: Degrades over time. Check stretch recovery on vintage.

burn_test.warning: Only perform outside of store on purchased items

hand_feel_test.drape: Silk and rayon drape fluidly; polyester has stiffer drape
hand_feel_test.moisture: Natural fibers absorb moisture; synthetics feel clammy
hand_feel_test.recovery: Quality wool springs back; polyester stays compressed
hand_feel_test.warmth: Wool and silk feel warm; synthetics feel room temperature

premium_natural.description: High-value natural fibers to actively seek

cashmere.burn_test: Burns slowly, smells like burning hair, leaves crushable ash
cashmere.care_notes: Prone to pilling and moth damage. Check carefully.
cashmere.hand_feel: Extremely soft, lightweight warmth, slight halo

cotton.burn_test: Burns quickly with yellow flame, smells like burning paper, leaves gray ash
cotton.care_notes: Look for premium cotton types. Basic cotton less valuable unless vintage.

leather.care_notes: Check for cracking, peeling, dryness. Suede check for bald spots.

linen.burn_test: Burns quickly with yellow flame, smells like burning paper, leaves gray ash
linen.care_notes: Wrinkles easily - not a defect. Gets better with age.
linen.hand_feel: Crisp, cool, textured, becomes softer with wear

silk.burn_test: Burns slowly, smells like burning hair, leaves crushable ash
silk.care_notes: Dry clean or hand wash cold. Water spots possible.
silk.hand_feel: Smooth, cool to touch, slight texture variation, drapes beautifully

wool.burn_test: Burns slowly, smells like burning hair, leaves crushable ash
wool.care_notes: Check for moth damage around seams and underarms.
wool.hand_feel: Warm, springy, slightly scratchy (varies by type)

quality_synthetics_vintage.description: Vintage synthetics that have collectible value

acetate.care_notes: Dissolves in acetone (nail polish remover). Dry clean.
acetate.hand_feel: Smooth, silk-like appearance, less drape than silk
acetate.notes: Common in vintage linings and evening wear. 1950s-1970s pieces can be valuable.

nylon_vintage.care_notes: Heat sensitive. Check for yellowing and brittleness.
nylon_vintage.notes: Early nylon (1940s-1960s) has collector value in lingerie and hosiery.

rayon_viscose.care_notes: Weakens when wet. Many vintage pieces dry clean only.
rayon_viscose.hand_feel: Silk-like drape, cool to touch, can be slippery
rayon_viscose.notes: Vintage rayon (pre-1970s) often higher quality than modern. Look for 1940s-1960s pieces.

emerald.notes: Almost all emeralds are oiled/treated - expected, not a defect

ruby.notes: Many vintage rubies are synthetic - still valuable but less so

sapphire.notes: Comes in many colors beyond blue. Kashmir blue most valuable.

amethyst.notes: Common but deep purple specimens and vintage pieces have value

garnet.notes: Common in Victorian jewelry. Demantoid and tsavorite more valuable.

jade.notes: Highly valued in Asian markets. Color and translucency determine value.

opal.notes: Australian black opal most valuable. Check for doublets/triplets.

pearl.notes: Natural pearls extremely rare. Vintage cultured still valuable.

turquoise.notes: Much fake turquoise exists. Vintage Native American pieces valuable.

bakelite.notes: Art Deco bakelite jewelry highly collectible. Many fakes exist.

lucite.notes: Vintage lucite with inclusions or designs collectible

paste.description: Lead glass cut to imitate gems, used in Georgian/Victorian pieces
paste.notes: Antique paste in good condition highly collectible

rhinestones.notes: Vintage signed rhinestone jewelry (Weiss, Eisenberg, etc.) very collectible

leather_quality_tests.edge_test: Real leather has fibrous edges; synthetics have smooth/plastic edges
leather_quality_tests.grain_test: Real leather has natural variations; synthetics are perfectly uniform
leather_quality_tests.smell_test: Real leather has distinctive organic smell; synthetics smell plastic or chemical
leather_quality_tests.warmth_test: Real leather warms to touch quickly; synthetics stay cool
leather_quality_tests.water_test: Real leather absorbs water slightly; synthetics bead water

bonded_leather.identifying: Peels and cracks easily, uniform appearance

genuine_leather.description: Misleading term - often lowest quality real leather
genuine_leather.identifying: Label says 'genuine leather' without other qualifiers

pleather_pvc.identifying: Plastic appearance and smell, cracks when cold

pu_leather.identifying: Plastic smell, perfect uniformity, peels over time

corrected_grain.description: Sanded and embossed to hide imperfections

nubuck.description: Top grain buffed to create nap
nubuck.identifying: Similar to suede but finer grain

suede.identifying: Soft napped surface, less durable than grain

cordovan.description: Shell cordovan from horse, extremely durable
cordovan.identifying: Dense, waxy, distinctive rolling rather than creasing

exotic.notes: High value but verify authenticity. Many fakes exist.

full_grain.description: Highest quality, outermost layer with natural grain intact
full_grain.identifying: Natural variations, pores visible, develops patina

nappa.description: Full grain leather that's been specially treated for softness
nappa.identifying: Extremely soft and supple, often used in luxury goods

top_grain.description: Sanded and refinished surface, still high quality
top_grain.identifying: More uniform appearance, less natural variation

meta.purpose: Materials identification guide for vintage clothing, shoes, and jewelry

brass.identifying: Yellow color, may tarnish green, no precious marks

bronze.notes: Copper-tin alloy, used in vintage costume

copper.notes: Develops green patina, used in artisan jewelry

pewter.notes: Tin alloy, soft, dull gray, used in vintage brooches

pot_metal.notes: Cheap alloy, common in vintage costume, can be valuable if designer signed

gold_filled.description: Thick layer of gold mechanically bonded to base metal
gold_filled.notes: Good value, can last decades. Look for fraction (1/20 = 5% gold by weight)

gold_plated.description: Very thin gold layer, will wear off

rolled_gold.description: Similar to gold filled but thinner layer
rolled_gold.notes: Less gold than gold filled, still decent quality

vermeil.description: Gold plating (minimum 2.5 microns) over sterling silver
vermeil.notes: Has silver value even if gold wears. Must be on sterling to be vermeil.

coin_silver.notes: Older standard, common in antique pieces

colors.white: Alloyed with palladium/nickel, often rhodium plated

10k.notes: Minimum to be called gold in US/Canada

14k.notes: Most common in US/Canada, very durable

18k.notes: High quality, good balance of purity and durability

24k.notes: Pure gold, very soft, rarely used in Western jewelry

palladium.notes: Similar to platinum but lighter, less expensive

platinum.notes: Heavier than gold, naturally white, does not tarnish

acid_test.method: Apply acid to small scratch mark, observe reaction
acid_test.notes: Definitive but destructive. Use only on purchased items in inconspicuous spot.

results.no_attraction: Could be gold, silver, platinum, copper, brass, aluminum
results.slight_attraction: Some white gold alloys have slight magnetic response
results.strong_attraction: Ferrous metal, plated base metal, not precious

weight_test.notes: Gold is heavy (19.3 g/cm³), platinum heavier (21.5), silver lighter (10.5)
